title: 112_hr6293
content: The Act titled "Servicemembers Rights Enforcement Improvement Act of 2012" modifies the plaintiff affidavit filing requirement for default judgments against servicemembers. Paragraph (1) of section 201(b) of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act is amended to require the plaintiff to file an affidavit with the court before seeking a default judgment, stating whether the defendant is in military service or unable to determine their military status. The plaintiff must file an affidavit before seeking a default judgment, stating if the defendant is in military service. A diligent investigation is required to determine the defendant's military status. SEC. 3 amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to increase civil penalties for violations. SEC. 4 enforces rights of uniformed service members against states and private employers. The amendment to section 4323 of title 38, United States Code, allows the person on whose behalf a complaint is submitted to intervene in the action and obtain appropriate relief. The Attorney General must notify the person on whose behalf a complaint is submitted within 60 days of receiving a referral, informing them of the decision to commence an action or the expected timeline for making such a decision. If a decision is expected, the person must be notified within 30 days of the decision being made. Whenever the Attorney General has reasonable cause to believe that a State or private employer is engaged in a pattern or practice of resistance to the rights provided under this chapter, the Attorney General may commence an action for relief. The Attorney General may not initiate action for relief under paragraph (1) regarding a complaint. Standing for actions under this chapter is limited to the Attorney General or a person claiming rights under subsection (a). A conforming amendment expands the scope of claims under subsection (h)(2). SEC. 5. Subpoena power for special counsel in enforcement of employment and reemployment rights of members of uniformed services with respect to federal executive agencies. Section 4324 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow the Special Counsel to subpoena Federal employees and agencies for testimony and document production. The Merit Systems Protection Board can enforce compliance with subpoenas. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act allows the Attorney General to issue civil investigative demands for documentary material relevant to an investigation before commencing a civil action. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands for relevant documentary material before starting a civil action. The provisions of section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, apply to the authority to issue, use, and enforce civil investigative demands under this Act. References to false claims law investigators or interrogatories are modified for this Act. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands for relevant documentary material before starting a civil action under this Act. The definitions related to false claims law do not apply, and provisions regarding qui tam relators are also not applicable. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands for documentary material, including production, inspection, copying, and written questions. The provisions of section 3733 of title 31 apply to the authority to issue, use, and enforce civil investigative demands under this section. References to false claims law investigators or investigations are considered references to investigators or investigations under this subchapter. References to interrogatories as written questions do not need to be under oath, and definitions related to 'false claims law' and provisions regarding qui tam relators do not apply.
